Looking back at Jupiter's chaotic southern hemisphere...üåÄ‚Å£
‚Å£
After a close flyby of Jupiter on Nov. 3, 2019, our @nasajuno spacecraft's JunoCam captured this striking view of the giant planet, showing massive cyclones and chaotic clouds. When the image was taken, Juno was traveling at about 85,000 mph (137,000 kilometers per hour) relative to the planet. A little more than an hour earlier ‚Äî at the point of closest approach to the cloud tops ‚Äî the spacecraft reached speeds relative to Jupiter in excess of 130,000 mph (209,000 kilometers per hour).‚Å£
‚Å£
Citizen scientist Ali Abbasi created this image using data from the spacecraft's JunoCam imager. ‚Å£
‚Å£
Image data: NASA/JPL-Caltech/SwRI/MSSS‚Å£
Image processing by AliAbbasiPov, ¬© CC BY‚Å£
‚Å£
#jupiter #planets #solarsystem #nasa #juno #clouds

Spider webs. Shattered glass. Fractal art. ‚Å£
‚Å£
What does this image evoke for you? This photo was captured by NASA astronaut Jessica Meir as the International Space Station (@ISS) orbited ~250 miles (~400 km) over London‚Äôs glittery nightscape.‚Å£
‚Å£
Image Credit: NASA/Jessica Meir‚Å£

*Record scratch, freeze frame*‚Å£
‚Å£
You're probably wondering how I ended up in this situation...‚Å£‚Å£
‚Å£‚Å£
On a Nov. 22 spacewalk, @europeanspaceagency astronaut Luca Parmitano caught a ride over to the worksite outside the International Space Station (@ISS) aboard the station's robotic arm. Known as Canadarm2, the robotic arm was operated from inside the station by astronaut Jessica Meir. At the worksite, Parmitano and fellow spacewalker Andrew Morgan (@AstroDrewMorgan) performed repairs on the Alpha Magnetic Spectrometer instrument, a cosmic particle detector. Repairs continue in the next spacewalk on Monday, Dec. 2.‚Å£ ‚Å£
‚Å£
Credit: NASA & ESA‚Å£
‚Å£‚Å£
#spacewalk #astronaut #robots #nasa #esa‚Å£

üé∂ Baby stars! üé∂ ‚ú® This galaxy might be bursting with star formation and stellar newborns. ‚Å£
‚Å£
Our @NASAHubble space telescope turned its powerful eye towards galaxy NGC 3749, over 135 million light-years away from Earth. This galaxy shows strong emission lines (signs of emission from elements within a galaxy's spectrum of light), suggesting that it has plenty of star-forming material and energetic new stars. ‚Å£
‚Å£
This study technique, known as spectroscopy, is used by astronomers to understand a galaxy‚Äôs type and composition, the density and temperature of any emitting gas, the star formation rate, or how massive the galaxy‚Äôs central black hole might be. ‚Å£
‚Å£
Image Credit: ESA/Hubble & NASA, D. Rosario et al.‚Å£
‚Å£
#hubble #galaxy #babies #stars #universe #esa #nasa

Did this debris shield spark joy?‚Å£
‚Å£
Sometimes you need to let go of what no longer serves you!‚Å£
‚Å£
On the first spacewalk to repair the International Space Station's cosmic particle detector, @AstroDrewMorgan and @europeanspaceagency astronaut Luca Parmitano removed a debris shield to access the work site. It was too big to take inside, so the best option was to jettison it behind @iss, where it will disintegrate in the upper atmosphere. This video was taken on Nov. 15.‚Å£
‚Å£
On Friday, Nov. 22, the two astronauts will once again venture into the vacuum of space to resume repair work on the particle detector, called the Alpha Magnetic Spectrometer. Watch live coverage starting at 5:30am ET on nasa.gov/live.‚Å£
‚Å£
Credit: NASA/Andrew Morgan‚Å£
‚Å£
#NASA #Declutter #SparkJoy #TakeOutTheTrash

It may look like a veiny eyeball, but Jupiter's moon Europa is more than meets the eye. üëÅÔ∏è‚Å£
‚Å£
For the first time, scientists have detected water vapor above the icy moon's surface, giving us further evidence that oceans of liquid water may exist beneath Europa's crust. ‚Å£
‚Å£
üíß Water is one of the main ingredients necessary for life, making Europa an alluring destination for exploration. Scientists will soon be able get close enough to this intriguing moon to settle their lingering questions. The Europa Clipper mission, expected to launch in the mid-2020s, will survey the moon up close and sample molecules in its atmosphere.‚Å£
‚Å£
Seen here is a view of Europa made from images taken by the Galileo spacecraft in the late 1990s during a flyby. ‚Å£
‚Å£
Credit: NASA/JPL-Caltech/SETI Institute‚Å£
‚Å£
#nasa #europa #jupiter #space #science #astronomy #solarsystem #h2whoa

Finally. ‚Å£
‚Å£
After decades of searching, astronomers have found what they‚Äôve been looking for: a galaxy cluster where large numbers of stars are being born at its core. ‚Å£
‚Å£
Galaxy clusters are the largest structures in the cosmos that are held together by gravity, consisting of hundreds or thousands of galaxies. For decades, astronomers have looked for galaxy clusters containing rich nurseries of stars. Instead, they found powerful, giant black holes pumping out energy and keeping the gas too warm to form many stars. Until now. ‚Å£
‚Å£
Data from @NASAHubble and @nasachandraxray is revealing new details about how the most massive black holes in the universe affect their host galaxies. Click the link in the bio for more info ‚¨ÜÔ∏è‚Å£
‚Å£
Image credit: X-ray: NASA/CXC/SAO/G.Schellenberger et al.; Optical:SDSS‚Å£
‚Å£
#NASA #GalaxyCluster #BlackHoles

No matter the similarities and differences, every galaxy is beautiful in its own way. üíú üí´‚Å£
‚Å£
In this image from @NASAHubble, we see a galaxy very similar to our own Milky Way. NGC 772 is a spiral galaxy. From a glowing center, bright specks of star formation weave into dark ripples of cosmic dust. ‚Å£
‚Å£
NGC 772 differs from our home galaxy in that it‚Äôs a ‚Äúpeculiar‚Äù spiral galaxy ‚Äî meaning it is odd in size, shape or composition. However, this doesn't change how stunningly beautiful it is. ‚Å£
‚Å£
Image credit: ESA/Hubble & NASA, A. Seth et al.‚Å£
‚Å£
#Galaxy #NASA #BeautyIsEverywhere‚Å£

Why We're Sending Rockets into Earth‚Äôs Leaky Atmosphere

Our scientists launched rockets from the top of the world! üåéüöÄ In the tiny Arctic town of Ny-√Ölesund, where polar bears outnumber people, winter means three months without sunlight. The unending darkness is ideal for those who seek a strange breed of northern lights, normally obscured by daylight. When these unusual auroras shine, Earth‚Äôs atmosphere leaks into space.

Our scientists traveled to Ny-√Ölesund to launch rockets through these auroras and witness oxygen particles right in the middle of their escape. Piercing these fleeting auroras, some 300 miles high, would require strategy, patience ‚Äî and a fair bit of luck. This was our VISIONS-2 mission, and this is their story.

VISIONS-2 was just the first of many. Over the coming months, rocket teams from all over the world will launch rockets into this region as part of the Grand Challenge Initiative‚ÄîCusp, an international collaboration to study the mysteries of the polar atmosphere.

Read more: https://go.nasa.gov/VISIONS2blog

#nasa #space #rocketscience #rocketlaunch #science

5, 4, 3, 2, 1, 0... Lift-off! üöÄ ‚õàÔ∏è 50 years ago, Apollo 12 launched into a dark and rainy morning sky. ‚Å£
‚Å£
With Apollo 12 at about 6,600 feet altitude, observers on the ground saw lightning striking the launch pad. The Saturn V rocket was unaffected and continued to operate normally. But in Mission Control, data on controllers‚Äô displays turned garbled. Luckily, a quick-thinking flight controller, John Aaron, had a fix. The crew onboard the spacecraft reset an obscure system, and data returned to the screens in Mission Control. Once Apollo 12 mission commander Pete Conrad understood the cause of the excitement, he radioed to Houston, ‚ÄúI think we need to do a little more all-weather testing.‚Äù ‚Å£
‚Å£
Five days later on Nov. 19, 1969, the Apollo 12 lunar module Intrepid landed on the Moon in a region called the Ocean of Storms, approximately 950 miles west of where Apollo 11 landed and only 535 feet from our robotic Surveyor III mission.‚Å£
‚Å£
Images Credit: NASA‚Å£
‚Å£
#apollo #apollo12 #launch #rocket #nasa #history #saturnv

Tiny planet Mercury transits the Sun üëÄ‚Å£‚Å£
‚Å£‚Å£
On Nov. 11, Mercury crossed between Earth and the Sun - a rare event we won't be able to see again until 2032. Our Solar Dynamics Observatory, which views the Sun in a variety of wavelengths of light in the extreme ultraviolet, tracked Mercury's journey.‚Å£‚Å£
‚Å£‚Å£
Credit: NASA's Scientific Visualization Studio ‚Å£‚Å£
‚Å£‚Å£
#sun #transit #mercury #mercurytransit #solarsystem #nasa

There‚Äôs a storm brewing in the solar system! üå©Ô∏è‚Å£
‚Å£
Our @NASAJuno spacecraft captured this stunningly detailed look at a cyclonic storm in Jupiter's atmosphere during its 23rd close flyby of the planet. ‚Å£
‚Å£
Juno observed this vortex in a region of Jupiter called the ‚Äúnorth north north north temperate belt,‚Äù one of the gas giant planet‚Äôs many persistent cloud bands. These bands are formed by the prevailing winds at different latitudes. The vortex seen here is roughly 1,200 miles (2,000 kilometers) wide.‚Å£
‚Å£
Citizen scientist Kevin M. Gill created this image using data from the spacecraft's JunoCam imager when the spacecraft was about 5,300 miles (8,500 kilometers) from Jupiter‚Äôs cloud tops above a latitude of about 49 degrees. ‚Å£

Image credit: Image data: NASA/JPL-Caltech/SwRI/MSSS‚Å£
Image processing by Kevin M. Gill, ¬© CC BY‚Å£
‚Å£
#NASA #Jupiter #SolarSystem #Swirls #Clouds

‚ú®‚ÄúWe are made of star-stuff. We are a way for the cosmos to know itself.‚Äù‚ú® Today we remember planetary scientist Carl Sagan on his birthday. ‚Å£
‚Å£
Within a galaxy hosting around 300 billion stars, here @NASAHubble has captured a mere handful or two. These stars fall within NGC 1333, located about 1,000 light-years away in the constellation of Perseus. The cool gas and dust concentrated in this region is generating new stars whose light is then reflecting off the surrounding material, lighting it up and making this object‚Äôs lingering presence known to us.‚Å£
‚Å£
#NASA #Hubble #Space #Stars #Astronomy #CarlSaganDay

The "intricate, mesmerizing patterns of the International Space Station (@ISS) solar arrays." ‚òÄÔ∏è‚Å£
‚Å£
The second image here is a close-up taken by @Astro_Jessica on Nov. 7 during a photo survey of the arrays, which convert solar energy to electrical power. ‚Å£
‚Å£
In the space station's orbit 220 miles above Earth, the best source of energy is sunlight. When the station is in the Sun, about 60 percent of the electricity collected by its solar arrays is used to charge the station's batteries. The batteries then provide power to the station's systems during nighttime passes around Earth. ‚Å£
‚Å£
Images Credit: NASA‚Å£
‚Å£
#spacestation #solarpower #sun #solarcells #nasa #iss

The glow of the Milky Way arcs across a sea of stars... and planets! üåå‚Å£
‚Å£
This panorama of the southern sky was created with 208 images from a year of observations by our Transiting Exoplanet Survey Satellite (TESS) mission. Swipe through the images to see TESS's discoveries: first, the host stars of 29 confirmed exoplanets (worlds beyond our solar system), and second, more than 1,000 candidate planets astronomers are now investigating. ‚Å£ ‚Å£
To find exoplanets, the four TESS cameras capture a full sector of the sky every 30 minutes to search for transits. Transits occur when a planet passes in front of its host star from our perspective, briefly and regularly dimming its light. ‚Å£
‚Å£
Images Credit: NASA/MIT/TESS and Ethan Kruse (USRA)‚Å£
‚Å£
#milkyway #nightsky #panorama #exoplanets #stars

Not all galaxies are lonely. Some have galaxy squads. ‚Å£
‚Å£
NGC 1706, captured in this image by @NASAHubble, belongs to something known as a galaxy group, which is just as the name suggests ‚Äî a group of up to 50 galaxies which are gravitationally bound and relatively close to each other. ‚Å£
‚Å£
Our home galaxy, the Milky Way, has its own squad ‚Äî known as the Local Group, which also contains the Andromeda galaxy, the Large and Small Magellanic clouds and the Triangulum galaxy. Click the link in the bio for more info ‚¨ÜÔ∏è‚Å£
‚Å£
Image credit: ESA/Hubble & NASA, A. Bellini et al.‚Å£ #galaxy #squadgoals #hubble #cosmos #universe

Cue a jaw-dropüòÆ‚Å£
‚Å£
Behold, our beautiful planet Earth in all its natural splendor, captured from 250 miles above by the International Space Station (@ISS) commander Luca Parmitano. ‚Å£
‚Å£
As you read this, six humans are orbiting planet Earth at 17,500 mph in a football-field sized microgravity laboratory. During their time on the space station, they conduct important science and research that not only benefits life here on Earth, but will eventually help us send humans deeper into the solar system than ever before.‚Å£
‚Å£
Credit: @EuropeanSpaceAgency / Luca Parmitano‚Å£

3‚Ä¶2‚Ä¶1‚Ä¶ LAUNCH! üöÄ Today at @NASAWallops Flight Facility in Virginia, we launched more than 8,200 pounds of science, supplies and hardware to crew members living and working aboard the International Space Station.‚Å£
‚Å£
At 9:59 a.m. EDT, @NorthropGrumman's #Antares rocket, with #Cygnus spacecraft onboard, lifted off our home planet as the @ISS was traveling over the south Atlantic southwest of Cape Town, South Africa, at an altitude of 257 statute miles. ‚Å£
‚Å£
Along for the ride are research investigations, hardware for future spacewalks and a vest intended to protect astronauts from harmful radiation in space and other cargo that is scheduled to arrive at our orbiting laboratory on Monday, Nov. 4. ‚Å£‚Å£
Images Credit: (NASA/Bill Ingalls)‚Å£
